# Introduction

This is a R markdown file. We can write in Markdown and export to different formats whilst writing R and running it.

For each R function, you can run `?function` to get a manual page.

```

```

```{r}

```

# Variables

```{r}
x = 1
2 -> y ## Handles left and right-hand assignment.
4 > x + y
```

# Vectors

```{r}
x = c(1, 2, 3, 4) ## c for "Combine".
y = (5:8) ## 5, 6, 7, 8.
z = c(9:11, 20) ## 9, 10, 11, 20.
x + y + z
```

```{r}
x = c(10, 2, 41, 55)
```

```{r}
sum(x)
```

```{r}
length(x)
```

```{r}
mean(x) ## Average.
```

```{r}
max(x)
```

```{r}
min(x)
```

```{r}
median(x)
```

```{r}
sort(x) # Ascending.
```

```{r}
rev(sort(x)) # Descending.
```

```{r}
summary(x)
```

```{r}
diff(x)
```

```{r}
## Default for label names is the variable name for x, and "Index" for y.
## There's no title ("main") by default.
plot(x, xlab="Numbers", ylab="Position of the Number", main="Numbers and their positions")
```

```{r}
hist(x) ## Histogram.
```

# Dataframes

R has some generic dataframes we can play around with.

```{r}
summary(beaver1)
```

This one has body temperature measures from a beaver.

We can get a specific column by using `$`:

```{r}
beaver1$temp
```

We can easily add columns with assignment. Using assignment, all the values of our new column are set to the passed value:

```{r}
beaver1$legs = 4
head(beaver1, n = 5) ## Shows the first five entries.
```

We can perform arithmetic on dataframes. With this, we can create a fahrenheit column for `beaver1`, for example:

```{r}
beaver1$fahrenheit = (beaver1$temp * 9 / 5) + 32
head(beaver1, n = 5)
```
